description.plain:
Modest Mouse is an American indie rock band formed in 1992 in Issaquah, Washington, by singer/lyricist/guitarist Isaac Brock, drummer Jeremiah Green and bassist Eric Judy. The band’s lineup has dramatically changed over the years, and the only original members still in the band to date are Brock and Green. For a lineup timeline, see here.

Modest Mouse released their debut album This Is a Long Drive for Someone with Nothing to Think About in April 1996 and have released six studio albums to date. They gained mainstream recognition with their April 2004 effort Good News for People Who Love Bad News and it is their commercially best-selling album, being certified Platinum by the RIAA.

Modest Mouse’s name is derived from a passage from the Virginia Woolf story “The Mark on the Wall” which reads:

I wish I could hit upon a pleasant track of thought, a track indirectly reflecting credit upon myself, for those are the pleasantest thoughts, and very frequent even in the minds of modest, mouse-coloured people, who believe genuinely that they dislike to hear their own praises.

songs.full_title: Float On by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Float On

description.plain: Unarguably Modest Mouse’s most popular song, “Float On” is about how no matter what happens it could always be worse, look at the bright side. The track was the band’s mainstream breakthrough and the lead single of their fourth LP, Good News for People Who Love Bad News. It was nominated for a Grammy in 2005 for Best Rock Song, which went to U2’s “Vertigo”

songs.full_title: 3rd Planet by Modest Mouse
songs.title: 3rd Planet

description.plain:
The “3rd Planet” in the song refers not only to the Earth itself, but also the third member of a family, a child.
Many fans believe that the song is about a family dealing with the loss of a child due to a miscarriage, and that upon finding out about the child’s death, the protagonist of the song is suddenly swept up in all of the potential that has been lost forever.
The lyrics of the song are disjointed, suggesting a stream of consciousness and flashbacks to the moment of conception.

description.plain: “Dramamine” is a track that resembles driving down a long desert highway with nothing to look at or think about. It is described perfectly by the title, like being in a mindless sort of state to battle some obstacles like motion sickness. Dramamine is over the counter medication to combat motion sickness.

songs.full_title: Bukowski by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Bukowski

description.plain:
In this song Isaac is expressing how one might conform to traditional societal ideologies to prevent ostracizing themselves from everyone else – making life slightly less lonesome. Although at the same time, he questions whether or not it is worth sacrificing your individual identity in order to make your views/personality more palatable for others.

The example he gives for this case is the life of the writer, Bukowski, the song’s namesake. Charles Bukowski has a slightly ambiguous affiliation with religion, some describe him as an atheist while others describe him as an agnostic. One of his most cited quotes explaining his views on faith is as follows:

“For those who believe in God, most of the big questions are answered. But for those of us who can’t readily accept the God formula, the big answers don’t remain stone-written. We adjust to new conditions and discoveries. We are pliable. Love need not be a command nor faith a dictum. I am my own god. We are here to unlearn the teachings of the church, state, and our educational system.”

Isaac describes his outlook on life slowly changing into Bukowski’s, but he questions whether or not this is a good thing as he fears this would lead to being ignored. He goes on to question the alternative to his changing life outlook, pointing out an apparent discrepancy in creationism: If God gave man life, why does he take it away?

Isaac then ends the song in the same way it began, not knowing the answer to his own question even after spending the whole day thinking about it.

songs.full_title: Ocean Breathes Salty by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Ocean Breathes Salty

description.plain:
The second single from the record, it usually gets overshadowed by Modest Mouse’s break-out track “Float On,” which propelled them into superstardom for a brief period.

While that track was quite poppy, “Ocean Breathes Salty” is much closer in sound to their earlier albums: mournful, jangly guitars mixed with the trademark and unique vocals of Isaac Brock. The music video mirrors the message in the track. A child is seen dragging Brock (playing the role of an injured wild bird) around, as Brock sings about a soul who is destined to carry the ghost of a lover or friend through life with them. The child eventually buries Brock with his bandmates, only for them to spring up from the ground and continue to entertain the child, symbolic of the final line.

The track didn’t chart, a let down after “Float On” reached number 1 on the US Alternative Songs chart.

songs.full_title: Trailer Trash by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Trailer Trash

description.plain:
“Trailer Trash” was written by lead singer Isaac Brock about the time he spent living in a trailer park in Oregon during 3rd and 4th grade. In the Pitchfork documentary about The Lonesome Crowded West, Brock reflects back on the song, saying:

To be honest it was fine, it wasn’t as bad as I made it sound. I was a kid, what do you do? […] You ride your bike around the trailer park […] It’s a neighborhood to you.

songs.full_title: Teeth Like God's Shoeshine by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Teeth Like God’s Shoeshine

description.plain:
“Teeth Like God’s Shoeshine,” the opening track on Modest Mouse’s The Lonesome Crowded West, illustrates Brock’s lyrical capacity like no other song. There are many innuendoes slung at ravage commerce in this song, but there is more. The “more” lies in the essence of Brock’s lyrical prowess: the human element.

Acute to his talents, these words illuminate two contrasting ideas at once. Many of these verses can be only one sided, but I encourage listeners and readers to seek the deeper and more personal aspect of these truthful words. With Brock, there is always more to one side than just one.

For a quick example look at the annotation for the line that states “take ‘em all for the sense of happiness that comes from hurting deep down inside.”

In some way Brock is always talking about the essence in himself and in everyone else as well as in those on whom he’s specifically commenting.

songs.full_title: Lampshades on Fire by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Lampshades on Fire

description.plain:
First appearing in Modest Mouse’s live set in 2011, “Lampshades on Fire” was the lead single from their 2015 LP, Strangers to Ourselves.

Catchy like their preceding albums' first singles, “Dashboard” and “Float On”, “Lampshades on Fire” employs a danceable rhythm and an extended partying metaphor in lyrics which focus on humanity’s penchant for destruction.

songs.title_with_featured: The Ground Walks, with Time in a Box

description.plain:
“The Ground Walks, with Time in a Box” is the fourth single from Modest Mouse’s 2015 album, Strangers to Ourselves, following “Lampshades on Fire,” “Coyotes,” and “The Best Room.”

Much like the first three singles, “The Ground Walks” discusses the ways humans have been depleting the Earth’s resources, but with an extended instrumental outro that recalls the band’s earlier work.

songs.full_title: Gravity Rides Everything by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Gravity Rides Everything

description.plain:
Rushing to see/know everything right now, gravity is the force that slows you down, but it ‘isn’t anything at all’ – unless you pay attention to it.

There’s a buddhist concept at work through the entire song.  The rush to know/to be/to write on the world, contrasted with the desire for rest, the knowledge that everything will evolve the way it is meant to evolve.

It’s not a giving in or an oppression by an oppressive force – gravity – whether that means the forces that makes it harder to achieve or to stand upright.

We fight against this force, which causes our flesh to sag and milk (you can figure out the sexual reference here yourself) to fall to the floor, but in truth, this is the plan of life. We are stuck with the beautiful constraints of operating within this weighted environment.

It’s not a giving in or an oppression by an oppressive force – gravity – whether that means the forces that makes it harder to achieve or to stand upright.

We fight against this force, which causes our flesh to sag and milk (you can figure out the sexual reference here yourself) to fall to the floor, but in truth, this is the plan of life. We are stuck with the beautiful constraints of operating within this weighted environment.

songs.full_title: Custom Concern by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Custom Concern

description.plain:
“Custom Concern” is the third song on Modest Mouse’s first full-length album, This is a Long Drive for Someone with Nothing to Think About. The album was re-issued in November 2014 by Glacial Pace.

In his review of the re-issue, Pitchfork writer Brian Howe describes the recurring themes in Brock’s songs,

The urban paranoia of post-punk seeps into wide-open rural, looming industrial and encroaching suburban vistas, all alike in their sinister, hypnotic repetition. With the first words of Long Drive, “traveling swallowing Dramamine,” a sense of drugged conveyance through some grand monotony settles over us. We seem to glimpse empty landscapes with twisty bits of things blowing through them in the window of a train. Strip malls and parking lots, monuments and steeples, empty fields and dark forests scroll by in a purgatorial loop.

songs.full_title: Broke by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Broke

description.plain: Track 3 off of 1998’s Building Something Out of Nothing. This song was also used in the 2010 Chris Malloy documentary 180 degrees South, which followed Jeff Johnson from Ventura, California to Patagonia, Chile retracing the 1968 trip that Yvon Chouinard and Doug Tompkins took in their Ford E-Series Econoline Van. After finding footage of the 1968 expedition, Johnson decided to make climbing the Corcovado Volcano in Patagonia as his life goal and, after speaking to Chouinard and Tompkins, planned his own journey.

description.plain:
“Little Motel” is a slow-paced, contemplative song about the mourning of someone dear to the narrator. The song’s arrangement is performed in classic Modest Mouse style, which consists of muted drums and weaving guitars, building up to a brilliant instrumental breakdown that features an entrancing guitar melody.

Additional insight into the song’s meaning is perhaps best derived from the song’s time-reversed music video. The video depicts a mother with her son, who is seen at the beginning being tucked into bed in a motel room. In the end (or beginning of the events chronologically), it is revealed that the the son was dying in a hospital. The mother decides to remove the monitors from the son, and drives him to have dinner, and eventually to a motel. Presumably, the mother cannot stand the thought of her son dying in a cold hospital room.

“Little Motel” is the third single to be released from the album We Were Dead Before The Ship Even Sank.

songs.full_title: Ansel by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Ansel

description.plain:
The fifth song on Modest Mouse’s 2015 album Strangers to Ourselves, “Ansel” was first performed in 2012 in Frost Amphitheater at Stanford University.

The song is inspired by the death of Isaac Brock’s brother, Ansel Vizcaya, who died in an accident on a mountain in June of 2004. The track marks a rare, personal moment from the songwriter, who typically obscures his feelings with copious amounts of metaphor.

songs.full_title: Spitting Venom by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Spitting Venom

description.plain:
Modest Mouse takes a look at an unhealthy relationship, and compare the verbal fighting to spitting venom.
Finally, Isaac Brock looks past the couple’s “fucked up history”, and ends on a positive note by considering the benefits of honest communication, even if that communication wasn’t inherently positive whatsoever.

songs.full_title: Coyotes by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Coyotes

description.plain:
“Coyotes”, the second single released from Modest Mouse’s 2015 LP Strangers to Ourselves following “Lampshades on Fire”, explores the predatory nature of humanity.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UW5Or7bIVJk

The music video features footage from “Passenger”, a 2010 short film inspired by a real-life incident of a coyote who wandered onto an express train at a Portland, Oregon airport, which also inspired the song “Light Rail Coyote” by fellow ‘90s Washington indie rock legends Sleater-Kinney.

description.plain:
“The Best Room” is the third single released from Strangers to Ourselves, following “Lampshades on Fire” and “Coyotes.”

The track is a criticism of a typical Western lifestyle full of greed and minor concerns.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]

songs.full_title: Interstate 8 by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Interstate 8

description.plain:
Interstate 8 is a southwestern, interstate highway that spans across the south of Phoenix to the south of San Diego. The number 8 also represents an infinite loop—always driving but never getting anywhere.



“Interstate 8” starts with an explosion of fading, whammy melodies which are followed by muted and distorted vocals. The explosive start and chorus is accompanied by the emotional shouts of Isaac and serene vocals of Nicole Johnson.

songs.title: Sugar Boats

description.plain:
The ninth track on Modest Mouse’s sixth full-length album, Strangers To Ourselves. After “Lampshades on Fire,” this was the second song from Strangers to be played live, debuting in April 2012 at Stanford University, then titled “Heart of Mine.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jk-Fgtr09n4

The album version features expanded instrumentation from the original live performance, adding honky-tonk piano and a horn section to the main guitar line.

songs.full_title: Lives by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Lives

description.plain:
“Lives” can be broken down into three parts:


A cynical view on life.
A “positive” view on life.
A cynical view on life.



In the middle of the song, the tone becomes upbeat and motivational but slowly takes a turn back to the cynical view.

The second part of the song ends with “Why fight this?” This marks the transition back to the cynical view. The implication is that the positive part of the song was attempt to try to believe by assertion.

“Lives” provides insight into how depression and other mental illnesses affect someone’s thoughts. Despite wanting to feel better and be more positive, you just spiral back into your original state. No matter how much you want it to be true or how hard you try.

songs.title: Convenient Parking

description.plain: “Convenient Parking” is a song lamenting urban sprawl—a major theme on Lonesome Crowded West. Lead singer Isaac Brock moved from Montana to Issaquah, Washington as a kid. He said, “Very quickly I saw it get mall-fucked. Not just the town, the area in general. It happened very quickly. It kind of pissed me off.”

songs.full_title: Tiny Cities Made of Ashes by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Tiny Cities Made of Ashes

description.plain:
One take on Tiny Cities is that the character whose point of view the song is from is discussing contemplating death, or possibly suicide. The “tiny city made of ashes” would be a  cemetery–or more likely a columbarium–in this case.

Another interpretation involves parallels between the lyrics and F. Scott Fitzgerald’s The Great Gatsby.

songs.title: Tundra/Desert

description.plain: “Tundra/Desert” is a dark satire on society and the worthlessness of it all, from child stars to fancy drinks at the bar. We attach meaning to it all, but does it really matter?

songs.full_title: Life Like Weeds by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Life Like Weeds

description.plain: It’s talking about dismissing people as an obstacle, then realizing life is too short to bullshit yourself into hating those that try to help you and not saying how you feel (weeds grow around rocks; “I could have told you all that i love you), and in fact they aren’t an obstacle, but an anchor (switching from saying you’re JUST a rock to me to saying you’re a rock to me)

songs.full_title: Pups to Dust by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Pups to Dust

description.plain:
The eighth track from Modest Mouse’s 2015 album, Strangers to Ourselves, “Pups to Dust” was one of the first songs to surface; a very early version was played on a 2011 episode of Don’t Move Here, a documentary series about music industry personnel in Portland, Oregon. Modest Mouse’s lead singer, Isaac Brock, is featured in the fifth episode of the series' second season.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T8gOV3dwx-M

songs.full_title: Pistol (A. Cunanan, Miami, Fl. 1996) by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Pistol (A. Cunanan, Miami, Fl. 1996)

description.plain:
The fourth track from Modest Mouse’s sixth studio album, Strangers to Ourselves, “Pistol (A. Cunanan, Miami, Fl. 1996)” is named after serial killer Andrew Cunanan, who murdered five people, the last of whom was famous fashion designer Gianni Versace. Cunanan killed himself in a Miami houseboat in 1997, eight days after murdering Versace.

It’s unknown what Cunanan was up to in 1996, but Modest Mouse hypothesizes with this distorted dance track set to a processed drum beat.

songs.full_title: Sleepwalking (Couples Only Dance Prom Night) by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Sleepwalking (Couples Only Dance Prom Night)

description.plain:
“Sleepwalking (Couples Only Dance Prom Night)"is anachronistic at its core, something out of the pre-rock-and-roll of the mid-1950s. The echoing, arpeggiated guitar tracks like a lullaby, with distinctive Brock pinch-harmonics squeaking through during lulls in the lyrics. The song itself is clearly about young love, about being seventeen and not quite knowing what to do with the angst and the adoration. It’s about quiet nights with pilfered alcohol and learning how to spend time with a person.

The track actually borrows its melody from the 1959’s “Sleep Walk” by Santo and Johnny Farina. Betsy Brye also released a version in 1959 with different lyrics.

songs.full_title: Fire It Up by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Fire It Up

description.plain:
This song is about living a good life in spite of the material world we live in.

The intro lines, as spoken, sound like the question, “Is there enough?”

I believe this is intentional, especially when you consider how the end of the song is an answer to this question, stating, “We always had it all.”

The speaker starts the song thinking that they do not have enough, that they are too poor to live life well. By the end of the song they realize that they didn’t need money, and even though they may have struggled at times, they managed to have an adventurous life with many fond memories.

The moral of this song is that you do not need to be materially wealthy to live life to the fullest, and that sometimes only by rejecting the concerns of the material world can we find real meaning and joy.

songs.full_title: Black Cadillacs by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Black Cadillacs

description.plain: “Black Cadillacs” is about the collapse of a co-dependent relationship, death, and not having closure. The song’s title is a metaphor for Brock’s relationship dying out, black Cadillacs act as a hearse at a funeral transporting the deceased.

annotatable.title: Black Cadillacs

body.plain: “Black Cadillacs” is about the collapse of a co-dependent relationship, death, and not having closure. The song’s title is a metaphor for Brock’s relationship dying out, black Cadillacs act as a hearse at a funeral transporting the deceased.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
And it's true we named our children after towns
That we'd never been to
And it's true that the clouds just hung around
Like black Cadillacs outside a funeral
And we were done, done, done
With all the fuck, fuck, fucking around

[Chorus]
You were so true to yourself
You were true to no one else
Well, I should put you in the ground
I've got the time, I got the hours
I got the days, I got the weeks
I could say to myself
I've got the words, but I can't speak
Well, I was done, done, done
With all the circ-circ-circling 'round

[Bridge]
I didn't die and I ain't complaining
I ain't blaming you
I didn't know that the words you said to me
Meant more to me than they ever could you
I didn't lie and I ain't saying
I told the whole truth
I didn't know that this game we were playing
Even had a set of rules
[Verse 2]
We named our children after towns
That we'd never been to
And it's true that the clouds just hung around
Like black Cadillacs outside a funeral
And we were laughing at the stars
While our feet clung tight to the ground
So pleased with ourselves
For using so many verbs and nouns
But we were all still just dumb, dumb, dumber
Than the dirt, dirt, dirt on the ground

[Chorus]
Well, wings on flames, kings with no names
Well, this place just ain't got right air right now
You were so all over town but still so Crayola brown
Well you should run 'round yourself right now
And we were done, done, done
With all the fuck, fuck, fucking around
Circling 'round8EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: Medication by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Medication

description.plain: “Medication” is the b-side track of the “Life of Arctic Sounds” single issued in 1996, and the fourth track on the compilation album Building Nothing Out of Something.  It’s separated into three parts.  The first part represents the depressive stage of bipolar disorder, the second part transitions into the manic stage, and the third part transitions back into a depressive stage.

songs.full_title: Of Course We Know by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Of Course We Know

description.plain:
“Of Course We Know,” the closer from Modest Mouse’s sixth album, Strangers to Ourselves, zooms out from the environmental message that permeates most of the record to focus on a broader, existential crisis: with death inevitable and society keeping us ignorant, why would we ever want to learn anything?

This was the fifth song officially previewed from the record before its release, following “Lampshades on Fire,” “Coyotes,” “The Best Room,” and “The Ground Walks, with Time in a Box.”

songs.full_title: The Whale Song by Modest Mouse
songs.title: The Whale Song

description.plain:
“The Whale Song” is not about whales, but is more about wails, its “the wail song.” Isaac’s guitars wails in pain, and the lyric’s are mournful of the past and regret; how the narrator was unable to find a way out. The extensive lyrical repetition and rephrasing is reflective of the obsession we have over regret especially when we’ve failed ourselves or others.

The guitar soloing wails and hits tones that are uncomfortable to listen to, and many people might find this a hard piece to listen to. This is good as it reflects someone wailing out in pain, which can make people cringe is discomfort. So instead of trying to hears whale sounds think of wails and screams.

Then again this song also could be interpreted to be about whales contrary to the above, which would make sense of some of the lyrics. Like this is about a whale hunt, “I’m rising up, wish I was sinking down” could be about how a whale would rather be sinking back into the ocean than being pulled up by whalers or perhaps to be delivered to Sea World. Then the narrator is the scout of a pod of whales and feels responsible for leading his group into danger.

The two lyrical interpretations as either about being about human suffering or whales is blurred as the lyrics are not direct. This could be Isaac saying the way we interpret this song is indicative of who we are. Like if the line “I’m rising up, wish I was sinking down” is confusing from a human perspective but makes sense to a whale’s then a listener’s assumption about the identity of the narrator will lead to different conclusions. Is this song narrated by a clever human wordsmith “the wail song” or is meant to be from an alien perspective of another species “the whale song”. There isn’t an explicit answer in the lyrics, Brock shows our difficulty in knowing the other.

  Do we think whales can have complex emotions and thoughts like a human narrator? Are these lyrics only anthropomorphizing whales as a way to express Isaac’s concern over environmentalism when in fact he doesn’t know what whales think about or feel?

songs.full_title: Fly Trapped in a Jar by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Fly Trapped in a Jar

description.plain:
On a literal level, “Fly Trapped In a Jar” is Isaac Brock rambling off a chilling nautical tale: a boatload of men dock in a small town for a brief spell only to be captured by the townsfolk and ritually sacrificed to the ground which “needs to be fed.”

Like the rest of the album, the song also works as a parable for the current state of our civilization: we struggle to save ourselves like the fly with one wing trapped in a jar, like those men held by the townsfolk, but we may already be doomed to an inescapable fate.

songs.full_title: Ice Cream Party by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Ice Cream Party

description.plain:
On the psychedelic song, “Ice Cream Party,” Isaac Brock pleads friends to join him for an ice cream party, quite possibly from the point of view of a child.

The song is unique to the Modest Mouse catalogue, featuring high pitch-effected vocals, sitar and a spooky flute-like synth solo, creating an altogether dreamy, yet moody soundscape. The song still holds familiarities of the band’s signature sound, such as the shimmering chorus-saturated guitar that is featured prominently on the album Good News For People Who Like Bad News.

“Ice Cream Party” was teased by the band on November 12th, 2019 via a mysterious countdown on the band website and a post on Reddit. The song’s release was also accompanied by a music video, as well as an official Modest Mouse ice cream, made by Portland ice cream shop Ruby Jewel.

It should be noted that “Ice Cream Party” is also the name of Brock’s Portland studio and hangout, which he developed in 2012. It is located in an old check-printing factory in Goose Hollow. Brock describes the studio’s vibe in a statement (May 2017):

There was a lot of drinking and weed-smoking and shit, […] Half of us stay up until 7 am.

This song is the the band’s third song to be released in 2019.

songs.full_title: Fuck Your Acid Trip by Modest Mouse
songs.title: Fuck Your Acid Trip

description.plain:
In “Fuck Your Acid Trip”, Isaac Brock sets the scene for the The Golden Casket: he’s had enough tripping and wants to go home. The thrill of adventure and the illusory no longer appeal to him because he’s seen it all before and has come to prioritize his family and responsibilities. As Riff Magazine pointed out, he’s gone from the good times killing him–when he declared he was “fed up with all that LSD”—to being the one to harsh the vibe himself.

Whether the acid trip in question is just the story of the song or also a deeper metaphor for the unreal nature of current events is a matter of how you interpret it.

description.plain: A Life of Arctic Sounds is a 7" single, with the A side running at 45 RPM and the B side at 33 RPM, released by Modest Mouse in 1996 and is featured on their compilation album, Building Nothing Out of Something. The original record with red and black vinyl ran with an unknown limited quantity, the pale blue version was limited to 328 copies, and production of a white vinyl continued until 2010. A new issue of a clear version is in production by Suicide Squeeze Records.

The original record with red and black vinyl ran with an unknown limited quantity, the pale blue version was limited to 328 copies, and production of a white vinyl continued until 2010. A new issue of a clear version is in production by Suicide Squeeze Records.

songs.full_title: The Sun Hasn't Left by Modest Mouse
songs.title: The Sun Hasn’t Left

description.plain:
“The Sun Hasn’t Left” is a gentle reminder that, while things really are bad, the world hasn’t ended just yet and there are still things to take joy in. Like Modest Mouse staples “Gravity Rides Everything”, “Float On”, and “Dashboard”, this is a break from Isaac Brock’s usual negativity. Unlike any previous Modest Mouse song, this one is much gentler in tone and sound. It’s likely a result of Brock’s desire to make children’s music. As he explained to Uproxx:

“It’s hard to be a dad and be as pessimistic as I want to be. There’s something good about being a parent and just being aware that, not for your sake, you don’t want this place to fucking suck. For anyone. I don’t want other kids to have to live in shitty situations, because I like my kids.”

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
Back to the middle and don't you remember?
Every day was another fish tank and your
Head swims around and you wrote us a letter
Saying things will get much better, go
Back to the middle and don't you remember?
Every night, there's a tiny porch lighting our
Chest pulls clouds of bugs to flutter
We felt love as it carried us, carried us

[Pre-Chorus]
Back to the middle and don't you remember?
Our head is a cage and the parrot loves to talk
[Instrumental Chorus]

[Verse 2]
We built a cabin and we built a castle
I just don't believe it was worth all the hassle, you know?
We lived in cities and we lived in caves
I guess I'd like to move back to the middle again

[Pre-Chorus]
Back to the middle and don't you remember?
Our head is a cage and the parrot, it won't shut up
[Instrumental Chorus]

[Verse 3]
Back to the middle and don't you remember?
Now and then, we would take our ladder and
See if we will climb to the heavens or
Shift our gaze, climb down to never go
Back to the middle and don't you remember?
Every winter, we would wish it were warmer and
Every summer, I will knit you a sweater
Scratch words in the dirt to remember that
We're up here right now, not forever
We'll be pulled right back down to the middle again1EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
Come on, man, I'm not the problem
Well, I'm not the one tryin' to push you around
So poison the well, our enemies are thirsty
They took our money and threw their own damn party, get it out

[Verse 2]
I'm not tryin' to push you around
Well, to push you around
Well, to push you around
The medicine makers, they are tryin' to kill us
Yeah, they know what a cure is
But they bet that's bad for business, get it out

[Chorus]
Gimme, gimme, gimme some sorta lift
So pass me that feather down, down
Gimme, gimme, gimme something better than this
This bad taste in my mouth

[Post-Chorus]
Uh uh

[Bridge]
To push you around, man
To push you around, well
I'm not tryin' to push you around, well
Whoever prints the money says where you spend it
And just like magic, it's right back in their pocket
So poison their well, your enemies are thirsty
Yeah, I'd hate to see you gettin' too distracted
'Cause I'm not the one tryin' to push you around
Oh, spit that rind out your mouth
Let's get that taste out your mouth
[Chorus]
Gimme, gimme, gimme some sorta lift
So pass me that feather down, down
Gimme, gimme, gimme something better than this
This bad taste in my mouth

[Outro]
I'm not the one tryin' to push you around
Well, get that taste out your mouth
Now spit that rind out your mouth
Now get it out2EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
Out of breath and out of cash
Find yourself watching M.A.S.H
And every night on the couch
Woman says, "Let's take a drive on south"
Roll down the windows and open our mouths
Taste where we are and play the music loud
Stop the car, lay on the grass
The planet spins and we watch space pass
Walk a direction see where we get
I never knew nothin' so there's nothin' to forget
Get real drunk and ride our bikes

[Chorus]
There's so much beauty, it could make you cry
There's so much beauty, it could make you cry
There's so much beauty, it could make you cry
There's so much beauty, it could make you cry

[Verse 2]
The rich get money but never what they want
Find ourselves a new place to haunt
Climb up the fire escape
Do it 'til the ground looks far away
Go night swimming, leave our clothes on the ground
Even when we get busted we just stand there proud
It's the truth we all been wrong, make it up and let's move on
Playing cards we all get to act sly
[Chorus]
There's so much beauty, it could make you cry
There's so much beauty, it could make you cry
There's so much beauty, it could make you cryEmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.lyrics:

[Verse 2]

Well, here it comes

Well, here it comes
So now we're drowning in birthday cakes
Well, here it comes

[Bridge]
Keep it clean, I didn't mean to be mean

Here it comes

Well, here it comes
Speak about the future in the past tense

songs.lyrics:
[Chorus]
At the movies, eyes iced over
Walking sideways through them gutters
And you realize that the floor sticks to your feet like history
Well, don't you look at me
Like life don't hold you anymore mystery

[Verse 1]
Bag of splinters boiling over
On your back, expose your belly
Optimism doesn't change the facts
Just what you're gonna see
Like it was stated that we're walking salt and coal
Plants solidify sunshine, how this start I don't know
Causing feet and entire chain shoe stores
The sun's diary pulled up from deep canary holes
And when we read it, our skin, it becomes warm

[Chorus]
At the movies, eyes iced over
Walking sideways through the gutter
And you realize life sticks to your feet, you're history
I'm gonna slap that look off your face
Like life don't hold no mystery

[Verse 2]
All those red marks on our shoulders
Self back-patting, homemade trophies
Well, the past only exists as tiny bricks
We burn to release all, it's memory
I've had enough with rolling boulders, I want more moss on me
Clocks to splinters but time goes forward
And when them tree drop leaves your feet collect their memories
I guess all us snakes find our tails pretty damn tasty
[Verse 3]
I heard you mention that we're walking salt and coal
Plants solidify sunshine, how this start I don't know
Causing feet and entire chain shoe stores
The sun's diary pulled up from deep canary holes
And when we read it, our skin, it becomes warm

[Chorus]
At the movies, eyes iced over
Walking sideways through the gutter
And you realize life sticks to your feet, you're history
I'm gonna slap that look off your face
Like life don't hold no mystery1EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy
